backgroundRationale:
The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) Resident Fish RM&E project is a Columbia River Fish Accord project that began in 2008. The primary goal for the Resident Fish RM&E Project is to conserve, enhance and restore native fish populations in the blocked area above Grand Coulee Dam in Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries, and where appropriate provide opportunities for subsistence harvest by the Colville Tribal members and recreational anglers. The current work of the RM&E project focuses on the protection and conservation of Redband Trout populations on the Colville Confederated Tribes Reservation.

Rainbow Trout are a focal species in the Sanpoil Subbasin under the Intermountain Province Subbasin Plan (IMP) due to their recreational value as a sport fish and their cultural significance to the CCT (Gillin and Pizzimenti 2004). The Columbia River Redband Trout are a subspecies of rainbow trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992; McLellan and Lee 2010). Effective fisheries management of Redband Trout requires an understanding of population structure, complex historical management activities, geography, and life history strategies (McCusker et al. 2000; Spidle et al. 2003; Spruell et al. 2003; Small and Dean 2006; Small et al. 2007).

In order to properly manage the Redband Trout populations managers require a basic understanding of population dynamics and an understanding of survival in trends during key life-histories.  In 2010 the Colville Tribe began working with regional co-managers to develop a comprehensive plan to monitor the Redband Trout populations in the blocked area. The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (McLellan and Lee 2010) developed a Redband Trout Stock Assessment Plan that could be used by the co-managers to collect key life history information. 

This is the outline the CCT has used to develop the Resident Fish RM&E program to conduct stock assessment study on Redband Trout in the Sanpoil River. The project plans to implement four primary tasks which include monitoring abundance, monitoring recruitment, monitoring harvest, and monitoring escapement to assist with management decisions. The development of a multi-year data set will enable managers to monitor trends over time and address potential limiting factors.

This protocol describes Redband Trout Escapement monitoring in the Sanpoil River.

sampleDesigns.title: Redband Trout Escapement - Colville Confederated Tribes
Redband Trout Escapement analysis - Colville Confederated Tribes
Redband Trout Adult Escapement - Weir Trapping - Colville Confederated Tribes

objectives: The objective of this protocol is to collect, mark and estimate the number of Redband Trout returning to the Sanpoil River to spawn.
keyAssumptions:
Key assumptions for this project include: 

The weir trap set at the mouth of the Sanpoil River captures all sizes of adult Redband Trout entering the river throughout the year.
dataHandlingConsiderations: All data are recorded on water proof paper data sheets or with a field computer. Paper data is entered into Excel or the resident fish database weekly. Data collected on field computers are uploaded to the database at the end of every day.
qualityControlConsiderations: All data is reviewed by the lead filed biologist, then the project manager prior to all analysis or acceptance into the database.
reportingConsiderations: All BPA funded projects utilize the RM&E formatting process developed by BPA for annual reports. Data is summarized for the calendar year (Jan - Dec).
equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: All equipment (boots, rain gear, waders, and nets) are properly cleaned and stored after the field season is over.
rolesAndResponsibilities: Project Manager: Manages contracts, SOW, budgets, hiring, study designs, attends meetings, and collaborates with regional groups. Field Biologist: Works with project lead to implement daily field activities, managers technicians, orders all equipment and ensures data is collected properly. Technicians: Works closely with field biologist to ensure data is collected, equipment is maintained, and problems are solved.
qualifications: Field Biologist: Minimum four year accredited college degree. Typically field experience with appropriate methods, experience with data analysis, database management, and writing reports. Preference is given to applicants with boating (electrofishing) experience and PIT tag array design experience. Technicians: Minimum qualifications include: High school diploma, must maintain WA State Drivers license, have a good attendance record, work effectively in multicultural environments, must be willing to work late, weekend/holidays, and be physically fit enough to lift and pull heavy equipment. Preference is given to applicants with fisheries experience.
trainingRequirements: Personnel are trained in first aid and CPR classes, swift water rescue, and obtain WA State boaters card. If available, we attempt to provide access to excel training, word training, leadership training, and access to local conferences.
safetyConsiderations: Field crews that enter the river must wear Coast Guard certified personal flotation devices (PFD's). Only personnel that have passed a swift water rescue course are allowed in the river during high flows.
fieldScheduleNotes: Field equipment schedules are developed in collaboration with the project lead and lead field biologist. All gear is fished when water flows are below 500 cfs. Special care is taken above 500 cfs, usually gear is removed from the water to reduce equipment loss and damage
budgetConsiderations: Initial budgets constraints include designing and purchasing a resistance panel weir.
name: Redband Trout Escapement in the Sanpoil River (2008-109-00)
